raw_comment: The first thing I noticed about this graph is the fact that the appearance of the first leaf for the most part went from South to North at a relatively steady rate.  This certainly makes sense, since the Southern parts of the country are closer to the equator, and therefore, they are warmer.  However, I wonder why the areas in the Midwest saw their first leaf in May, a month or two later than many states that are located further North.  The animation of the graph really brings this to the attention of the person studying it, because the areas of the Midwest are the last parts of the white map to be colored in.  A good headline for this graph could be "Springing to Life" because it displays the gradual process of leaves and trees that are blooming to their fullest potential in the country.
ace_sentences: The appearance of the first leaf mostly moved from south to north at a relatively steady rate.
The southern parts of the country are closer to the equator than the northern parts of the country.
Parts that are closer to the equator are warmer than parts that are farther from the equator.
Therefore, the southern parts of the country are warmer than the northern parts of the country.
I wonder about the Midwest areas.
Many states are located farther north than the Midwest areas.
The Midwest areas saw their first leaf in May.
May is 1 or 2 months later than some other months.
Many states that are located farther north saw their first leaf 1 or 2 months earlier than May.
The animation brings this pattern to the attention of a person who studies the graph.
The Midwest areas are the last parts of the white map that become colored.
A headline for this graph could be "Springing to Life".
The graph displays a gradual process.
The leaves bloom to their fullest potential.
The trees bloom to their fullest potential.
